journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part J: Journal of Engineering Tribology

title-group.article-title: The tribological study of novel phosphorous–nitrogen type phosphoramidate additives in rapeseed oil

article-meta.aff: 1School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Key Laboratory for Thin Film and Microfabrication of the Ministry of Education, Shanghai Jiaotong University, People’s Republic of China
2Chongqing YaoPharma Co. Ltd, People’s Republic of China
3Chinese Academy of Sciences, Institute of High Energy Physics, People’s Republic of China

author-notes.corresp: Tianhui Ren, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Key Laboratory for Thin Film and Microfabrication of the Ministry of Education, Shanghai Jiaotong University, Shanghai 200240, People’s Republic of China. Email: thren@sjtu.edu.cn

abstract.p: Two novel phosphorous–nitrogen type phosphoramidate derivatives, dibutyl octadecylphosphoramidate and dimethyl 4-dodecylphenylphosphoramidate, were synthesized and applied as lubricant additives in rapeseed oil. Using a four-ball machine and standard method, the tribological behaviors of these additives in rapeseed oil were compared with commercial lubricant additives dodecan-1-aminium butyl 7-methyloctyl phosphate (coded T308B) and dibutyl phosphonate (coded T304). The results show that the phosphoramidate derivatives possess excellent antiwear, friction-reducing properties and good extreme pressure capacities. The tribological mechanism was investigated by X-ray absorption near edge structure spectroscopy. It is proposed that the prepared compounds as additives in rapeseed oil form a protective film on the rubbed surface, and the film contains phosphate and/or polyphosphate which can affect the tribological behavior.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Antiwear and extreme pressure (EP) additives are added to lubricating oils, especially gear oil and hydraulic oil to decrease wear and prevent seizure.1 A wide variety of antiwear and EP additives are commercially available, and the early additives contained chlorine, zinc, lead, etc. Lead naphthenates and chlorine-containing additives were extensively used in lubricating oils early, but environmental concerns have led to their disappearance.2 Zinc dialkyldithiophosphates are the best known and most widely used antiwear additives in engine and hydraulic oil.3,4 However, the concern for zinc as an environmental contaminant and for phosphorus poisoning of automotive catalysts has resulted in finding ashless and phosphorus-free or low-phosphorus replacements for both automotive and industrial applications. Without heavy metal elements, some heterocyclic compounds containing sulfur,5,6 phosphorus,7 and nitrogen8 could be promising substitutes as environmental friendly lubricating additives. Sulfur and sulfur–nitrogen additives are used to provide protection against high pressure, metal-to-metal contacts in boundary lubrication and good EP properties, but they lead to corrosion.9 Phosphorus and sulfur–phosphorus additives are used to provide protection against pressure and metal-to-metal contacts, too. Unlike sulfur additives, where their EP activity must be balanced against performance requirements for thermal stability and mild corrosivity toward copper, phosphorus-containing additives usually possess corrosivity control, but the phosphorus content is high. Ashless phosphorus–nitrogen additives with lower phosphorus content such as amine dithiophosphates, amine thiophosphates, amine phosphates, and phosphoramides can be easily prepared and extensively used as multi-functional antiwear/antirust additives.10–13 Low phosphorus and multi-function are the inevitable trends in lube processing.14 As to base oil, for environmental consideration, a renewable resource, rapeseed oil (coded RSO) is employed, because it is a good alternative to mineral oil for its environmental friendly, non-toxic, and readily biodegradable nature.15–17

In view of the fact that the reactions during the friction process are extraordinary perplexing and cannot be detected in situ up to date, surface analysis after rubbing system is an effective method to explore the mechanism.18 X-ray absorption near edge structure (coded XANES) spectroscopy is a convinced potential tool used to investigate the nature of tribofilm, because it can provide important chemical information about a sample without destroying it.14–19 A large number of studies about XANES analysis of tribofilm have been performed by many researchers, especially on phosphorous- and sulfur-containing additives.19–23

In this study, two novel phosphorous–nitrogen (P–N) type phosphoramidate derivatives, dibutyl octadecylphosphoramidate (coded DBOP) and dimethyl 4-dodecylphenylphosphoramidate (coded DMDP), were synthesized and applied as lubricant additives in RSO. Using a four-ball machine and standard method, the tribological behaviors of these additives in RSO were compared with commercial lubricant additives dodecan-1-aminium butyl 7-methyloctyl phosphate (coded T308B) and dibutyl phosphonate (coded T304). The results show that the phosphoramidate derivatives possess excellent antiwear, friction-reducing properties and good EP capacities. The tribological mechanism was investigated by XANES spectroscopy. It is proposed that the prepared compounds as additives in RSO form a protective film on the rubbed surface, and the film contains phosphate and/or polyphosphate which can affect the tribological behavior.

sec.title: General remarks
sec.p:
The chemicals and solvents were purchased from commercial suppliers from Shanghai Chemical Company, China and were used without purification prior to use. Commercial RSO which is provided by Grease Factory of China was used as the base oil without any further treatment. The two novel phosphoramidate derivatives, DBOP and DMDP, were synthesized according to the method shown in Scheme 1. Scheme 1.
Synthesis of P–N-type phosphoramidate derivatives.

The synthesized products were characterized by elemental analysis (PE 2400-II), IR (Paragon-1000 FT-IR), and 1H NMR (Varian mercury plus 400). The results of elemental analysis listed in Table 1 and IR spectra are in good agreement with the target compounds within the experimental error of lube additives. Table 1.
The elemental analysis of the synthesized compounds.
Items C (wt%) H (wt%) N (wt%) P (wt%)
DBOP 67.72 (67.64)a 12.31 (12.23)a 3.05 (3.03)a 6.52 (6.71)a
DMDP 65.32 (65.01)a 9.91 (9.82)a 3.90 (3.79)a 7.98 (8.38)a
a
Calculated value (oxygen being at balance).

sec.title: Synthesis of additives
sec.p: The novel additives were readily synthesized with the procedure as follows. In a 500-mL round bottomed flask, 26.9 g (0.1 mol) of octadecan-1-amine and 19.4 g (0.1 mol) of dibutyl phosphonate were added to some solvent, and catalysts were added to the above mixture with the temperature lower than 50°C. As the reaction proceeded, more and more precipitates were found. The obtained slurry was refluxed for 2 h till the reaction terminated. The solution was filtered, evaporated, and treated with routine protocol and finally produced 45.0 g (yield 97.5%) DBOP.

When octadecan-1-amine and dibutyl phosphonate were replaced with 4-dodecylaniline and dimethyl phosphonate, respectively, DMDP was obtained with 92.0% of yield as the same procedure as represented above.

sec.title: Friction and wear test
sec.p: The tribological performances such as friction-reducing and antiwear capacities of the additives are evaluated on an MRS-1J four-ball machine. The wear scar diameters (WSD) are measured by an optical microscope, and the friction coefficients are automatically recorded. The test conditions are rotating speed of 1450 r/min, testing duration of 30 min, and room temperature. The balls used in tribological test are in the size of 12.7 mm diameter and made of GCr 15 bearing steel (chemical composition: C, 0.95–1.05%; Si, 0.15–0.35%; Mn, 0.20–0.40%; P, 0.027%; S, 0.020%; Cr, 1.30–1.65%; Ni, 0.30%; Cu, 0.25%) with an HRC of 59–61 hardness. The load-carrying properties of the samples (maximum non-seizure load, PB and weld load, PD) are measured by an MQ-12-EP four-ball machine. Chinese National Standard GB3142-82 similar to ASTM D-2783 is adopted for all the tests.

sec.title: XANES analysis of the worn surface
sec.p: XANES analyses were performed at Beijing Synchrotron Radiation Facility (BSRF), situated at the 2.2 GeV storage ring, Beijing Electron Positron Collider (BEPC). Phosphorous K-edge spectra were collected on the double-crystal monochromator covering an energy of 2140–2180 eV. The photo-adsorption spectra were collected with fluorescence yield (FY) modes of detection to provide chemical information on the bulk of the reaction film.

sec.title: EP properties
sec.p: The EP properties of the additives in RSO were evaluated by the maximum non-seizure load (PB value) and the weld load (PD value).

The PB value of the RSO, 1.5 wt% DBOP/RSO, 1.5 wt% DMDP/RSO, 1.5 wt% T308B/RSO, and 1.5 wt% T304/RSO are shown as columns in Figure 1. The results show that DBOP and DMDP enhanced the PB values of base oil, indicating that these additives have good EP property. The PB value of DBOP which contains longer chain in molecular structure is higher than that of DMDP and T308B, suggesting that the additive containing shorter chain possesses poorer load-carrying capacities in RSO. Possible reason for this phenomenon is that the additive with longer chain can form thicker film on the surface. The PB value of T304 is higher than that of other additives, but the severity of corrosive wear far exceeds those of DBOP, DMDP, and T308B. The results show that acidic phosphate ester (T304) has more adsorption force than that of other phosphonate esters, and the results also indicate that the former can react with metal surface faster than others as the test only is performed in 10 s.24 Figure 1.
PB value of the additives (1.5 wt% additive in RSO, four-ball machine, rotary speed of 1760 r/min, 10 s).

The PD value of RSO, 1.5 wt% DBOP/RSO, 1.5 wt% DMDP/RSO, 1.5 wt% T308B/RSO, and 1.5 wt% T304/RSO, are shown as columns in Figure 2. The results match with the PB value and also indicate that the additive containing longer chain in molecular structure is harder to weld than those with shorter chain in RSO. The PB value of T304 is higher than other additives, too. The tendency matched well with PB value. Possible causes of these differences are the high adsorption force and reactivity of the acidic phosphate ester (T304).24 Figure 2.
PD value of the additives (1.5 wt% additive in RSO, four-ball machine, rotary speed of 1760 r/min, 10 s).

sec.title: Antiwear properties of phosphoramidate derivative additives
sec.p:
The variation of WSD with the concentration of the additives in RSO under 392N is shown in Figure 3. It indicated that DBOP, DMDP, and T308B can improve the antiwear property of RSO, whereas the DBOP is the best at the same concentration, and possible reason is that the additive with longer chain can form thicker film on the surface. And when DBOP or DMDP was added to RSO in different concentrations, the WSD varied a little. Because of the corrosive wear, T304 cannot serve as an antiwear agent in RSO. Suitable concentration of the additives is 0.5–1.5 wt% which can be added to base oil to enhance the antiwear property. It was reported that the antiwear properties of phosphorous-containing additives were related to hydrolytic stability,24 and the additives with high hydrolytic stability tended to have poor antiwear property. Possible reason for the phenomenon was that the adsorption of low-hydrolytic stability additives was stronger than that of the high-hydrolytic stability additives. Figure 3.
Effect of the concentration of additives on WSD (four-ball machine, 392 N, rotary speed of 1450 r/min, duration of 30 min).

In addition, curves in Figure 4 depict the antiwear properties of 1.5 wt% additives in RSO under different loads. It can be seen that the WSD of DBOP and DMDP are far less than those in RSO, which suggests that these additives can improve the antiwear performance of RSO under applied load 196–588 N. Moreover, DBOP shows better antiwear property at 196–588 N. T308B can reduce the WSD, but seizure happened when the load was added to 490 or 588 N. And the phenomenon of severe corrosive wear can also be observed when T304 was used. It is reported that film thickness decreased when load increased, and then WSD increased which matched well with the results as the indicated by the curves. Figure 4.
Effect of the applied load on WSD (four-ball machine, additive concentration of 1.5 wt%, speed of 1450 r/min, duration of 30 min).

sec.title: Friction-reducing properties of phosphoramidate derivative additives
sec.p:
From 0.5 to 3.0 wt%, different concentrations of synthesized compounds, T308B and T304, were added to RSO, and the variation of friction coefficient under 392 N is shown in Figure 5. The curve shows the friction coefficient significantly decreased when DBOP or DMDP was added to RSO. It is worth mentioning that the friction coefficient of RSO is 0.104, and 40.4% of which decreased to 0.062 when 1.5 wt% DBOP was added. DBOP shows excellent and stable friction-reducing properties at concentration of 0.5–3.0 wt% in RSO, and DMDP performs well. Suitable concentration of additives in base oil is 1.0–1.5 wt%. The decrease in friction coefficient of the samples can be explained that the additives form the adsorption film and/or reaction film on the rubbing surface.7 From Stribeck Curve, additives with low concentration formed thinner film which caused higher friction coefficient,1 while friction coefficient lower with the concentration enhanced or the film thickness increased. When T308B or T304 was added, the friction coefficients were just the same as the RSO, and the results were not satisfied. Figure 5.
Effect of the concentration of additives on friction coefficient (four-ball machine, 392 N, rotary speed of 1450 r/min, duration of 30 min).

Figure 6 shows the friction coefficient of 1.5 wt% synthesized compounds, T308B and T304 in the RSO with different applied loads. DBOP shows excellent and stable friction-reducing properties at an applied load of 196–588 N in RSO. When the additive was replaced with 1.5 wt% DMDP or T304, it gives poor performance. T308B reduces the friction coefficient in the load of 196–392 N, but seizure happened when the load was added. The friction coefficients tend to decrease with the increase of load, and the results of this load effect can match well with Stribeck Curve.1 Figure 6.
Effect of the applied load on friction coefficient (four-ball machine, additive concentration of 1.5 wt%, speed of 1450 r/min, duration of 30 min).

sec.title: Thermal films
sec.p:
Phosphorus K-edge X-ray absorption spectra can give the detailed information about the oxidation of phosphorus in a film or on a surface. Thermal films provide some useful information about the pathways of decomposition taking place before the friction process. Thermal films were prepared by the following procedure, the balls were put into 1.5 wt% additive-containing RSO and continued for 6 h at 150°C,24 and then they were ultrasonically cleaned with petroleum ether and dried before analysis. The analysis of the thermal films generated from additives can be helpful for explaining the chemical properties of the tribofilms. P K-edge XANES spectra of the thermal films are shown in Figure 7, in which the spectra of some model compounds are also listed and their peak positions along with some relevant model compounds are listed in Table 2. Figure 7.
P K-edge XANES spectra of the thermal films. Table 2.
Peak positions of the P K-edge (FY) spectra of thermal films generated from additives and model compounds.
P K-edge (eV)
Sample
1.5 wt% DBOP/RSO 2150.3
2152.2
2157.1
1.5 wt% DMDP/RSO
2152.3
1.5 wt% T308B/RSO
2152.3
1.5 wt% T304/RSO 2150.3
2152.1
2156.9
Compounds
FePO4
2152.3
Fe2P2O7
2151.6
2153.1 2157.0

As is shown in Figure 7, the thermal films generated from 1.5 wt% DMDP/RSO and 1.5 wt% T308B/RSO are solely composed of the peak of 2152.3 eV, which matches the model compound phosphate well. While the additives are replaced with 1.5 wt% DBOP or 1.5 wt% T304, the spectra are clearly different from the above two. The thermal films consist of the adsorbed additives and mainly polyphosphate that demonstrated by the fine structure of weaker peaks at about 2157 eV as literature reported.25,26 The results show that tribo-heat plays a very important role in the whole lubricating process. From the results of thermal films, we can also see that under tribo-heat conditions, the additive molecules were adsorbed on the iron surface, and then some molecules will react with iron and form the film on the surface.

sec.title: Tribofilms
sec.p:
The P K-edge XANES (FY) spectra of tribofilms generated from different additives in RSO are shown in Figure 8. The peak positions of each spectrum are shown in Table 3, and model compounds are also listed. Figure 8.
P K-edge XANES spectra of the tribofilms (different additives). Table 3.
Peak positions of the P K-edge (FY) spectra of tribofilms (different additives) generated from additives and model compounds.
P K-edge (eV)
Sample (a)
1.5 wt% DBOP/RSO 2150.3
2152.1
2157.1
1.5 wt% DMDP/RSO
2152.3
1.5 wt% T308B/RSO
2152.3
1.5 wt% T304/RSO 2150.3
2152.1
2156.9
Compounds
FePO4
2152.3
Fe2P2O7
2151.6
2153.1 2157.0

The tribofilms generated from 1.5 wt% DMDP/RSO shown in Figure 8(a) are simply composed of the model compound phosphate. From the XANES spectrum of 1.5 wt% DBOP/RSO, we can see that it is composed of the adsorbed additive, phosphate, and a little polyphosphate. When the additive was replaced with 1.5 wt% T304, the main compound changed to more additive, phosphate and polyphosphate. Associating these results with tribological data, the conclusion can be drawn that the tribofilms are composed of phosphate and polyphosphate, and a suitable ratio of the mixtures of phosphate and polyphosphate in the tribofilms will get better antiwear and friction-reducing performance than a single component. As can be seen from the spectroscopy of tribofilms, there is no weak pre-edge feature at approximately 2148.0 eV (the peak is the characteristic of Fe (III) phosphate according to the studies of Li et al.18 and Lin et al.19), which indicates that the cation in the films is mainly Fe (II) and not Fe (III).

The P K-edge XANES (FY) of tribofilms generated from different concentrations of DBOP additive in RSO are shown in Figure 9 and in which synthetic diester (coded DE) and mineral oil (coded 5CST) are also displayed. The peak positions of each spectrum and model compounds are listed in Table 4. From the spectra, difference of the polyphosphate is apparently found between 0.5 wt% DBOP/RSO and 3.0 wt% DBOP/RSO. Compared with 1.5 wt% DBOP/RSO, more polyphosphate was found when the base oil was replaced with DE or 5CST. Figure 9.
P K-edge XANES spectra of the tribofilms (different concentrations and base oils). Table 4.
Peak positions of the P K-edge (FY) spectra of tribofilms (different concentrations and base oils) generated from additives and model compounds.

sec.title: EP films
sec.p:
EP additives are expected to rapidly react with a surface under severe distress and prevent more catastrophic modes of failure such as scuffing (scoring), galling, and seizure. To further investigate the reaction under EP, EP films are also collected using XANES and shown in Figure 10. The peak positions of spectra and model compounds are listed in Table 5. Figure 10.
P K-edge XANES spectra of the EP films. Table 5.
Peak positions of the P K-edge (FY) spectra of EP films generated from additives and model compounds.
P K-edge (eV)
Sample
1.5 wt% DBOP/RSO 2150.3
2152.5
1.5 wt% DMDP/RSO
2152.3
1.5 wt% T308B/RSO
2152.3
1.5 wt% T304/RSO 2150.3
2152.3
2157.1
Compounds
FePO4
2152.3
Fe2P2O7
2151.6
2153.1 2157.0

From the spectra of EP films, we can see that they match the tribofilms well. It suggests that more polyphosphate are benefit for EP properties, and a little amount of polyphosphate is propitious to antiwear and reducing coefficient. If simple and sole phosphate was produced, the above two properties are both negative.

sec.title: Optical microscope micrographs
sec.p:
Figure 8 shows the optical microscope morphology of the worn surfaces. It can be seen that the scarred surface lubricated by the base stock RSO appears with wide cracks and deep furrow generated by severe wear and corrosion (shown in Figure 11(a)) which indicates that the corresponding boundary lubricating film may have poor strength. The same phenomenon was also found in Figure 11(d) which represented T304. But the scuffing on the worn surfaces lubricated by RSO containing the novel additive DBOP (Figure 11(b)) is greatly abated with only shallow scratch. When the additive was changed to DMDP or T308B, the scuffing on the worn surfaces was deeper as shown in Figure 11(c) and (e), but severe corrosion was not found neither. Figure 11.
Optical microscope micrographs (100×) of worn steel surfaces lubricated with (a) base stock, (b) 1.5 wt% DBOP in RSO, (c) 1.5 wt% DMDP in RSO, (d) 1.5 wt% T304 in RSO, and (e) 1.5 wt% DMDP in RSO (four-ball tester, load 392 N, speed 1450 r/min, duration 30 min).

list-item.p: Two novel P–N-type phosphoramidate derivatives were readily synthesized and applied as antiwear and EP additives in RSO. The tribological behaviors of these additives in RSO were compared with commercial additives T308B and T304 using a four-ball machine.

EP properties of DBOP and DMDP are better than those of base oil. T304 performed well in EP property but severe corrosion was found. Possible causes of these differences are the high adsorption force and reactivity of the acidic phosphate ester. The same phenomenon was found in antiwear property or WSD tendency.
Friction-reducing properties of DBOP performed far better than those of other additives. The results of concentration and load effect can match well with Stribeck Curve.

From the results of thermal films, we can see that under tribo-heat conditions, the additive molecules were adsorbed on the iron surface, and then some molecules will react with iron and form the film on the surface. From tribofilms, a suitable ratio of the mixtures of phosphate and polyphosphate in the tribofilms will get better antiwear and friction-reducing performance than that of a single component. From EP films, more polyphosphate are benefit for EP properties.
The optical microscope morphology of the worn surfaces can match antiwear and friction-reducing properties.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This study is funded by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (grant no. 20872092); Beijing Synchrotron Radiation Facility Project (grant no. SR06033) and Shanghai Synchrotron Radiation Facility Program (grant no. 11sr0564).

ack.title: Acknowledgments
ack.p: The authors gratefully thank Beijing Synchrotron Radiation Facility for the XANES analysis.
